title: What is Next.js?
content: Next.js is a React framework for building full-stack web applications with features like server-side rendering (SSR), static site generation (SSG), file-based routing, and API routes.
explanation: Next.js simplifies React app development by providing built-in solutions for routing, data fetching, optimization, and deployment.
sampleAnswers: Next.js is a React framework that enables server-rendered, statically generated, and hybrid applications with zero config.
It provides features like file-based routing, API routes, image optimization, and middleware out of the box.

title: What are the main features of Next.js?
content: Key features include: file-based routing, server-side rendering (SSR), static site generation (SSG), API routes, image optimization, automatic code splitting, and middleware.
explanation: These features enable full-stack development with optimized performance and SEO.

options.text: File-based routing, SSR/SSG, API routes, image optimization, middleware

title: What is the difference between Pages Router and App Router in Next.js?
content: Pages Router uses the `pages/` directory with client-side navigation. App Router uses the `app/` directory with React Server Components, nested layouts, and streaming.
explanation: App Router is the modern architecture with server-first rendering, layouts, and better data fetching.
sampleAnswers: Pages Router: `pages/` directory, client-side navigation, no layouts. App Router: `app/` directory, React Server Components, nested layouts, and streaming support.
App Router enables partial rendering with Suspense and automatic code splitting by route.

title: What are React Server Components in Next.js?
content: React Server Components (RSC) run only on the server, can access databases directly, and send only JSON to the client—reducing JavaScript bundle size.
explanation: RSCs enable zero-bundle-size components and direct backend access without API layers.
sampleAnswers: Server Components run on the server, fetch data directly, and send serialized output to the client—no hydration needed.
They’re a core part of Next.js App Router, enabling highly optimized full-stack applications.

title: How does Next.js handle routing?
content: Next.js uses file-based routing: files in `pages/` or `app/` automatically become routes based on their path.
explanation: No manual route configuration is needed—just create files in the correct directory structure.

options.text: File-based routing in pages/ or app/ directories
Manual route configuration with React Router

title: What is getStaticProps in Next.js?
content: `getStaticProps` is a Pages Router function that fetches data at build time for static generation (SSG).
explanation: It runs only at build time and returns props to the page component.
sampleAnswers: `getStaticProps` fetches data during build and generates static HTML. It’s ideal for content that doesn’t change often, like blogs or docs.
It only works in the `pages/` directory and cannot be used in the App Router.

title: What is getServerSideProps in Next.js?
content: `getServerSideProps` fetches data on every request for server-side rendering (SSR).
explanation: It runs on the server for every request, making it suitable for frequently changing or user-specific data.
sampleAnswers: `getServerSideProps` renders pages on the server per request—ideal for dashboards, real-time data, or authenticated views.
Like `getStaticProps`, it’s only available in the Pages Router (`pages/` directory).

title: How do you fetch data in the App Router?
content: In App Router, fetch data directly in Server Components using `async` components and the native `fetch()` API with automatic deduping and streaming.
explanation: Next.js extends `fetch()` with caching, revalidation, and deduping—no need for `getStaticProps` or `getServerSideProps`.
sampleAnswers: Write async Server Components that call `fetch()` directly. Next.js handles caching and deduping automatically.

Example: `async function Page() { const res = await fetch('...'); const data = await res.json(); return
{data.title}
; }`

title: What are API routes in Next.js?
content: API routes allow you to create serverless API endpoints inside the `pages/api` directory (Pages Router) or `app/api` (App Router).
explanation: Each file becomes an API endpoint, enabling full-stack apps without a separate backend.

options.text: Serverless functions in pages/api or app/api that handle HTTP requests

title: What is ISR (Incremental Static Regeneration)?
content: ISR allows you to update static content after build time by revalidating pages at a specified interval.
explanation: With `revalidate`, Next.js regenerates pages in the background when traffic hits them.
sampleAnswers: ISR combines the speed of SSG with the freshness of SSR. Use `revalidate: 60` in `getStaticProps` to update every 60 seconds.
It’s perfect for blogs, e-commerce, or dashboards where content changes periodically but doesn’t need real-time updates.

title: How do you handle authentication in Next.js?
content: Use NextAuth.js (Auth.js) for built-in providers, or implement custom auth with cookies, JWT, and middleware in API routes or Server Components.
explanation: NextAuth.js integrates seamlessly with Next.js and supports OAuth, email, and credentials providers.
sampleAnswers: Use NextAuth.js for quick setup with providers like Google, GitHub, or custom credentials. Store sessions in cookies for SSR compatibility.
In App Router, protect routes using middleware that checks for valid session cookies before rendering Server Components.

title: What is middleware in Next.js?
content: Middleware runs before a request is completed and can modify the request/response, rewrite URLs, or add headers.
explanation: It’s ideal for authentication, A/B testing, i18n, and bot protection.

options.text: Runs before request completion; can rewrite, redirect, or modify headers

title: How does Next.js optimize images?
content: Next.js uses the `next/image` component to automatically optimize images (resize, compress, modern formats) and lazy-load them.
explanation: It reduces bandwidth, improves LCP, and prevents layout shift with automatic sizing.
sampleAnswers: `next/image` serves optimized WebP/AVIF, resizes based on device, and lazy-loads offscreen images—no config needed.
It integrates with CDNs and local file storage, and supports blur-up placeholders.

title: What is the purpose of next.config.js?
content: `next.config.js` is used to customize Next.js build settings, like Webpack, Babel, environment variables, and experimental features.
explanation: It’s optional but powerful for advanced customization without ejecting.

options.text: Customize Webpack, Babel, env vars, and experimental features

title: How do you deploy a Next.js app?
content: Deploy to Vercel (official platform), Netlify, AWS, or any Node.js-compatible host. Vercel provides automatic SSR/SSG, edge functions, and preview deployments.
explanation: Vercel is optimized for Next.js with zero-config deployments and Git integration.
sampleAnswers: Push to GitHub and deploy on Vercel for automatic builds, preview URLs, and edge network caching.
For self-hosting, run `next build` and `next start` on a Node.js server—but you lose edge functions and ISR.

title: What are dynamic routes in Next.js?
content: Dynamic routes use bracket syntax (`[id].js`) to create pages for dynamic data, like `/posts/1` or `/users/john`.
explanation: In Pages Router, use `getStaticPaths` for SSG; in App Router, use dynamic segments like `app/posts/[id]/page.js`.

options.text: Bracket-based routes like [id].js for dynamic data

title: How do you handle environment variables in Next.js?
content: Prefix with `NEXT_PUBLIC_` to expose to the browser; others are server-only. Load from `.env.local`.
explanation: Non-prefixed variables are only available in Server Components and API routes—never exposed to client.
sampleAnswers: `NEXT_PUBLIC_API_URL` is available in the browser; `DATABASE_URL` is only in server code—keeping secrets safe.
Use `.env.local` for local development; Vercel lets you set env vars in the project dashboard.

title: What is the difference between SSG and SSR in Next.js?
content: SSG (Static Site Generation) renders pages at build time. SSR (Server-Side Rendering) renders on every request.
explanation: SSG is faster and cacheable; SSR is for dynamic, user-specific content.

options.text: SSG: build-time render; SSR: per-request render
SSR is always faster than SSG

title: How do you implement layouts in Next.js?
content: In App Router, use `layout.js` files for nested, persistent layouts. In Pages Router, use higher-order components or custom wrappers.
explanation: App Router’s `layout.js` is the modern, built-in way to share UI across routes.
sampleAnswers: In App Router, create `app/layout.js` to wrap all pages with a shared header/footer. Nested layouts are possible with folder structure.
Pages Router requires manual layout composition via component wrappers or context.

title: What is the purpose of the 'use client' directive?
content: `'use client'` marks a file as a Client Component, enabling interactivity, hooks, and event handlers in the App Router.
explanation: By default, all components in App Router are Server Components. Use `'use client'` only when needed for interactivity.
sampleAnswers: `'use client'` at the top of a file enables useState, useEffect, and event handlers—turning it into a Client Component.
It should be used sparingly to keep bundles small and leverage Server Components for data fetching.
